title-group.article-title: Do You Believe in Magic ? Exploring the Conceptualization of Augmented Reality and its Implications for the User in the Field of Library and Information Science

abstract.p: Augmented reality( A R) t echnology has implications for the ways that the field of library and information science (LIS) serves users and organizes information. Through coannteanlytsi s, the author examined how AR is conceptualized within a sample of LIS literature from th e, Library Information Sciencean d T echnology Abstracts (LISTA) database and Google Blogs post.i Tn hges author also examinedw hether Radical Change Theory (RCTa n)d thedi gital-­‐age principles of interactivity, connectivity, a nd access are present in the discussion of this technology. The analysis of data led to the identification of 14 categocroiemspr ising 1 32 total codes across sources within the data set. Thean alysis indicates that the conceptualization of AR, while inconsistent, suggests expectations that the technology wei lnlhance the user experienceT.hi s can lead to future examinations of user behavior, respon, sae nd observation of technologies likAeR. It seems an understatement to say digital technology is changing quickly. Cell phones are like small computers in our pock e;tws e have access to far greater computing resources in “the cloud” than we did just five years ago, and computers are processing at speeds once only a fantasy. This digital revolution includes the continued development of augmented reality (AR) applic.a Atito n s its simplest, AR is a blending of the physical environment with digital ele ments. While elements of AR, such as global positioning systems (GPS), quick response (Q R,a) n cdo d es virtual reality are not uncommon in LIS literature, rarely are these topics defined as AR. Information theory, information behavior, kwnoledge management, information architectur,ea nd digital literacy (to name only a few) are key areas of study within LIS, which can be central in Elizabeth Zak(e zak@dom.edu), is a djunct instructor at Dominican Univseitry, River Forest, Illinois.

sec.p: developing and exploring AR .

The focus on and the d efinitions ofut sheer w ithin LIS provide a much different perspective on the human aspect of engaging with digital information than is found within computer s cience. Literature on huma-nc­‐omputer interaction focuses more on the user as a piece of the system, with a shift only recently toward acknowledging this misdirected f1o,2c,3u,4s,5.,6,7,8 L ibraries and information agencies have the tools and sk—ilwlsith regard to s uer interaction with and use of information—to help answer questions relating to how the conceptualization of a technology like AR influences the use of the technolo gy.

Augmented Reality (AR) Define d What is ARr,ea lly? Ronald Azuma, a pioneer ainndno vator in the research and creation of AR applications, describes AR as a supplement to rea9lIi ty c.ombines the real and the virtual, aligning the virtual with the real environme1n0tA. R is part of a mixed reality contin,uau nmd “the technology dependso n our ability to make coherent space from sensory informa1t1ioT nh.i”s coherent space is dependent on several variables, one of which is A-Rt­‐ ’isme rea inl teractivity. AR applications cannot experience any delays in response time; if the real and vreirt muailsa aligned, it impedes the sense of reality. AR needs to happen at the same speed a—s v rieratlu a lilf e actions coinciding with human actions, and variable across use rs.

Some also view AR as a new media experience, adding to the growing list oitfer daigcietasl. l “While the pure technology provides a set of features that can be exploited, the features of the ne technology will develop into one or more particular forms within a particular historical and cultural setting.”12 T his includes “remediating” esxtiing media, such as film or stage productions, with AR components. As a result, AR is contextual and reliant on each personal experience, but it also borrows from earlier forms of media within those contexts and experiences. For this reason, it isnt im tpoo rta examine just how those within LIS are constructing AR as a concept. The rapid pace at which AR evolving and gaining in popularity s uggests those within t he f ield of LIS will need to be a ware of new applications for the technology as more and musoerres may come to expect access to and knowledge of this technology .

Much of the literature also references AR as beinegnh aannc ement. But what, exactly, is AR enhancing? T he a nswer includes our s enses and percept1io3ns so,ftware,14 o ur e motions and feelings,15 a nd q uestion-a­‐nswering programs1.6 A uthors use the ter men h ancement w ith no explanation of how it is defined in each piece of literature. Some assume more is always better. Missing is the voice of the user or consumer, whom authors refers u tobj e acst o a r w earer. The irony is many of these users are the ones creating, bu,ai lnddin g populating these AR worlds. I propose the field of LIS is in a prime position to address the missing piece of the research and discourse of AR. Within a library setting, AR can improve li brary instruction1,8 p rovide information retrieval about shelved books through recognition applications1,9 r econstruct and restore artifact2s0, a nd deliver services at point of need through QR codes21. O thers view AR as a technological breakthrough withre m exet potential in medical fields, such as n-oi­‐ nvasive surgical visualization, which c an d isplay the organs t hrough sensors placed on the body, helping medical practitioners and students to understand internal body functions2.2 AR is also said to performm seo of its “enhancements” in the classro2o3mA .ugmented books are growing in number and are expectede n toha nce c ollaboration and interactivitybe tween s tudents. Some allow more than one person to explore the same content at the same time or outside of the classroom through mobile technolog; yo thers give students the ability to rotate,, a tnildt manipulate viewing angles of various obje2c4ts. What they came up with resulted in a public art project using social networks, GPS software, and AR technolotghyat allowedu sers to interact withhe t art pieces through QR codes26. A gain and again, interactivity, connectiv,itay nd mobility of AR applications are highlighted as efficient and motivating factors in education and lea27r,n28i,n29g,3.0 Organizations are also testing AR applications for general public use. Museums and galleries contain AR virtual displays of artifacts and historic scenes, personalizing interactive experiences and providing multiple perspectives of events and artif3a1cTt sh.e Natural History Museum in London, for example, created the Attenborough Studio in 2009 for live events and the viewing of AR enhanced films32. A R tours are also offered on historic places and spaces. Augmented reality is already in use as a tour guidepli acpation,33 t o supplement paper map3s4, a nd even to reconstruct damaged historic sites35. A R is essentially a mutable form of displaying what are typically static objects and ideas. The use of AR is integrative. It can saturate real landscapes,, a p nladce spsaces with virtual characteristics; it can add to or hide objects in the environ36mM eannt.ipulation of the environment promotes “immersive experiences3,7” m ultifaceted for different people interacting with AR3.8 V irtual experiences are expected e tonh ance t he r eal-l­‐ ife experiences of the user. Spaces can become layered, or scaffold, not only through depth perception or AR software, but also through the user’s contextual life experienc3e9s. With growing widespread use, it is imperative for those in the L f iIeSld t o of understand this technology and how it is used. How will these applications be archived? Will institutions and organizations collaborate with users i n creating these applications? Will users expect librarians and other knowledge workers to help thue nmderstand and use the technology? Will libraries and other institutions use the technology, and if so, in what capacity? These are just some of the questions LIS professionals should be asking to ensure they are meeting user needs in relation to technology and the access of information through technology. This study provides a base for considering these questions, and the effects of AR, by situating the concept and expectations of AR within the field and aligning the conceptualization with Radical ChTahnegoery . The User Within AR and L IS The use of AR can bring with it an altering of emotional and psychological experiences. Pederson argues AR applications should be “hum-ca­‐enntric”.40 B ecause human beings “instrumentalize” technology such as AR, t hteec h nology itself should accommodate the human needs for AR 4 t1oo ls. For AR applications to be successful, they must display the human characteristics encompassing reactions to one another and the environm4e2nAt .pplications blurring the lines between theal re and the virtual, and engaging the person in ways that play on perception, are capable of changing the rea-ll­‐ ife perceptions and expectations of the user. AR caenit h beer a form of escapism for brief moments or an escape from what we know of a-sl­‐ife reaf ol r g ood43. What much of the research assumes is the desire for AR applications. Lacking is surveys of user desire for AR, or examination of potential negative consequences. A-f­‐ o ucsuesr is central to LIS and the values of librarianship. Within all thpeosteen tial uses, what is not being discussed is how creators of AR applications organize, categorize and choose the information contained within these applications. Much of the discussion surrounding the implications of AR use is left to those i fields ofph ilosophy and psychology, dealing in abstraction. The research and marketing of AR applications promote passive acceptance of AR technolog4i4e Ts .here comes a point when AR researchers must ask, to what extent are potential users aware of and desirRou asp opfli c Aations? The notion of people u asser s is quite similar to the contextualization of humasnub ajsect in this scientific literature, different from the notionu s oefr i n LIS. I nco mputer-s­‐cience literature,us ers are those reacting to AR and provgid i AnR researchers with content for AR modification as evaluators of the technology. Withcinom puter-s­‐cience literature, there is much talk of the user’s satisfaction with tested AR applicatio;n45st here also much talk t o hfe user’s position within the AR frame/environment.46 S imilar is the discussion of the user and the physical space of the AR application, and how the user responds to the AR func4t7ioU nses.r a nd s ubject a re terms used interchangeably in the scientific literature. These terms are largely i unnede,f indicating l ittle regard for the role of the human outside of objectification as a tool working in the AR env ironme Within the field of LIS, the notion ofus tehret a kes on different characteristic:su sers a re clearly patrons, human beings, for wichh L IS provides a service. Kuhlthau f ocuses on-c u­‐esnetrric treatment of information services with her Information Search Process m48oCd heal.tman’s theories of Information Poverty and Life in the Round both center in onfor tmheati on-s­‐eeking behaviors of r odinary people with everyday need49s. T here are many more theories and models demonstrating this user-c­‐entric focus in LIS. Case points to D ervin’s 1976 article “StrategDieesal fionrg withH uman Information N eeds: Information orCo mmunication?” as an exemplar of the shift in thinking about the role and n eeds of t he user i n51 LD ISe.rvin pointed to assumptions in researchi n ofnor mation-­‐ seeking, such as more information as better, and relevant information existing for every need. It is important to note whether there are assumptions now beiandge m in LIS literature with regard to user interaction with AR and how best to understand-c­‐ uenseterred design of AR application s. Bowler e t a l.d efine user-c­‐entered design as “[reflecting] the user, typically from a cognitive, affective or behavioral poino tf view, as well a s the social, o rganizational, and cultural contexts in which users function”5.2 T hese points of v ie—wthe cognitive, social, behavior,aal nd the lik—eall synchronize within AR applications. Bowler et al. s,t“ aWteith the increased u se oifg i dtal, networked information tools in daily practice and the emergence of the digital library and archive, it is impossible to separate the service from the system. In this context, understanding the user becomes more critical than ev”e5r3. W ith the advenot f AR and its dependence on user interaction, it is imperative to continue to address the role of the user.

O’Brien and Toms further the discussion by trying to define user engagement with technology. The authors define engagement as a process, composefd th oree states: a point of engagement, a period of engagement and then finally disengageme5n4 At .ttention to user needs and behavior as an individualized process is evident across LIS literature. Shu suggests user engagement in website design as a means s totre ngthening user relationships with organizations through a study of Web 2.0 [interactive internet applications5]5.I doughi, Seffah, a nd Kolski recommend integrating “personae,” or perceived personality types and characteristics, into-d u­‐esseirgn to addrses challenges in c reating software offering h ighly personalized serv5i6ceP sa.ng and Schauder take a community-b­‐ased approach to systems design, particularly in libraries and museums and encourage system designers to draw on the study of relationshipsnt aenradct iion within different communities as a means to gain insight into more-c­‐ uensetric design methods57. A user-c­‐entric focus has extended itself to catalog de5s8iag nd in formation-r­‐etrieval systems design.59 I t has been applied as a learning approach to organizational culture within li6b0ra ries. Scholarly research within the library is saalisdo t o have benefittedbe cause a user-c­‐entric focus informs how different types of users interact with information n w tihthei library61. T hrough an analysis of user language, us-ec­‐rentricity is also applied as a means to identify strategies for creating language tools f or web searchi6n2gS. uch studies are representative of the ways a- u­‐ser centric paradigm proliferates withiLnIS . These models and studies highlight the importance of the user perspective and how the user engages with information at various levels. Radical Change Theory (RCT), developed by Eliza Dresang in 1999, goes one step further and adds another elemehnet u tsoe r t-i­‐ nformation interaction: t he user’s interaction witohth er u sers and the response to the interactive applications and digital technologies in which information is become imngbedded. This element is mirrored in such applications as Twitter and Foquursare, which allow digital overlays of information to see if there are individuals “near you” also logged on to these networking applic a tions. The highly complex AR applications call for a highly complex view of human interaction with those applications. Radical Change Theory helps to explicate the characteristics of human expectations and interactions with information in digital formats. Coupled with an examination of AR discourse within LIS literature, RCT helps clarify how people, or users, are appnrgo a thchei changing information landscape. This study focuses on the u -sc­‐eerntric paradigm prevalent in LIS, seeking to understand the relationship between the conceptualization of an emerging technology and the role of the user. The researchq uestions g uiding this study atr hee following:
How is augmented reality (AR) conceptualized in L IS?

What is the role of the user in relation to AR as it is conceptualized in LIS? The aim is to understand how a specifically LIS-c­‐ uensetric focus canap ply to the conceptualization of AR and its use within libraries and cultural heritage instit u tions. The model for this study is Clement and Levine, which examined h-o1­‐w978 pre dissertations were published and what the concept of copyright was for thisosseert dations. The unit of sampling in their study was the written message, “defined as a complete statement or series of statements with a distinct start and e”nEd a.ch message under investigation required auth-s­‐oprecified semantic concepts. The researchesr then selected recording units, what they describe as “explicit assertions” pertaining to the publication of dissertations. The authors delineated explicit assertions as taking several forms, from a phrase within a sentencmeul ttoip ag e argument6.3 For the purpose of this study, I investigated written messages contained in the journals and blog posts I chose as well as links to other webpages or blog posts contained in the initial data set. Th semantic concept is the teramug mented reality. The recordingu nit is any explicit assertions made regarding augmented reality using the same range of form as Clement and 64 Le vine. In this study, I allied content analysis with Radical Change Theory (RCT). RCT focuses on the characteristics of interactivity, c onnectiitvy, a nd access, which are all dependent on measures of human connections through various forms of media. The characteristics of these principles are as follows: • Interactivity r efers to dynamic, use-ir­‐nitiated, nonlinear, nonsequentia, l complex

information behavior, and representation. • Connectivity r efers to the sense of community or construction of social worlds that emerge from changing perspectives and expanded association s . DO YOU BELIEVE IN MAGIC? | Z AK • Access r efers to the breaking of lo-sn­‐tganding information b arriers, b ringing entrée t o a wide diversity of opinion and opportun6i5ty. Content analysis of LIS literature related to AR through the RCT framework allowed m e to find connections between the conceptualization of a t echnology and how the conceptiuoanliz a functions within a given academic community. During the data analysis, Ied as s wehssether the characteristics of interactivity, c onnectivi,tya nd access are presnt in the descriptors of AR. Understanding how AR is brought into the discourse ofn L IS iliterature helps describtehe ways an emerging technology is developed as n ace cpot and as a tool throughe axnam ination of how researchers and practitioners perceive the need for and use o f AR.

Data collected from searches of Google Blogs andLi tbhrear y, Information Science and Technology Abstracts with Full Tex( tLISTA) database aided in understanding the conceptualization of AR and the role of the user in relation to the conceptualization. All the searches took pltahcreee ov er months, December 2021 to February 2013, and all searches centered on the search term “augmented reality”(t he t erm was enclosed in quotation marks in the search). box Through purposeful criterion sampling, all search results including the term “augmented reality” are includedin the i nitial list of d ata for analysis. I chose t he Google Blogs search engine because of its popularity, familiarity, ease of , ua sned variety of viewpoints. Blogs are an important source of d ata because t hey continue to increase in popularity acirsocsisplid nes, including LIS, and s erve as a way for people to communicate with one another and exchange infor6m6 Ta htieon L. ISTA database is easy to acce;sps rovided free to librarie;sf amiliar to students, facul,tya nd professionals in the field of ; LaI Snd covers a broad spectrum of general and specialized journals. Together, search results comprise both academic and popular, or mainstream, so u rces. I first gathered data from searches of Google Blogs. I conducted two separate searcehe s of th search term “augmented reality.” The first was in December 2012 and the w seacsoin d F ebruary 2013. The first search yielded 373 results and the seycioelndded 3 76. I used the advanced search function to limit the search to blog postings between Ju1n2e a 2n0d December 2012. The second search is limited to June 2012 to February 2013. Blog postings excluded from the final body of data for analysis includfeor eign-l­‐ anguage entries, duplicate items, vid-eo­‐only postings, and advertisements, r esulting in a fainl data set of 300 postin g s.

Library, Information Science and Technology Abstracts with Full Text (L I STA) After completing my search of Google Blogs, I gathered data from LISTA database searches. I searched the database once a month t fhorre e months, fromD ecember 2012 to February 2013. I divided each monthly search into three search types: first by - as­‐uutphpolried keyword, second by subject terms, and third by-t a­‐elxlt, resulting in nine searches. I did this to determine whether the results would differ arocss e ach search specification. I then cr-or­‐sesferenced these lists and removed duplicate andfor eign-l­‐ anguage results to compile one complete data set of 160 articles. Recording units from the articles, b,lo rg social media postings I collected from e th seesarches include explicit assertions concerning AR I then coded. For the purposes of this exploratory study, I developed codes inductively rather than approaching the data wpirtehd e ate rmined set of codes, as inductive codes arise from the interpretnat i oof the coded da6t7a.A n example of an assertion in the dataset includes the following, taken from an article in my pilot study:

AR is a very efficient technology for both higher education such as universities and colleges. Students in both schools can p irmove their knowledge and skills, especially on complex theories or mechanisms of systems or machi n.6e8ry I categorized these assertions according to the themes or codes with which they are embedded. For instance, in the assertion above, the nott hioant A R is efficient and capable of improving or adding to knowledge and skills could be categorized within similar assertions about the value or purpose of AR. After I organized the codes and categories, I determined which, if any, of these codes coincide w iht the digital age principles of Rin CtTeractivity, connectivity, a nd access. I developed 132 code.As further reduction of codes is not feasible given the myriad ways AR is defined across sources in the data set, which underscores the lack of consenjussuts h oonw AR is truly understood. I went through the codes and grouped them according to similarities and overarching themes labeled as categories. The 132 comdaekse up1 4 categories, listed itnab le 1. How is AR conceptualized in LI S? The L ISTA database n icludes m ore than5 60 journals from LIS and relatiendfor mation-s­‐cience fields such as communication and museum studies. Of the 77 LISTA sources included in the data set for this study, 46 sources are - pr­‐eeevriewed; 31 are not. Of those journals not - rp­‐eeveirewed, all of them focus specifically on issues in the media, technology, education or libraries. Based on my analysis, the categories or overarching themes most prominent in the LISTA data“ A sRet are as a new directio,n” “ AR as informationa,”l a nd “ AR a s an enhancemen.”t Taken together, these categories suggest AR can deliver information and the user can interact with information through an enhanced experience, which is a new direction in technology. Individually, these categories are loaded with implications based onco tdhees each category encompasses. The category of AR as a new direction itself incltuwdenst y -f­‐ ive c odes. The c odes i nclude assertions o f “AR as a new norm, ap lroviding opportunities” f or those willing to implement the technology because of its“p otential, v ersatile” ( yet debatable) range of uses from the business sector to education. Wh e vniewed as a growing trend, AR is creating a new world or platform for information delive r y.

Furthermore, in the LISTA sources AR is also vieweindfo arsm a tional. This categoryco mprises eight codes, all of which refer to the capability of AR to daetlhiveerr,, d gefine, presen,ta nd superimpose information rapidly. In this context for LIS, AR is another format for providing the user with information tailored to specific user needs. The ways AR can provide users with information are nestled in the view ofa s A R an enhancement. Within this category, AR is described as an enhancement of reality, communication, exp e,r iences and learning. Under this category there is little ARno wt iel nl h ance. The enhancement of the user experience is d irectly tied to t he i nfoatrimonal quality of AR. This enhancement rests on the engaging interactive qualities of AR fostering relationships and collaboration through the property of connectivity. Under this definition, the digital information AR displays or “criseat htees ” enhancement of the experience .

Sources in the data set also suggest AR enhances the learning experience through the digital images or objects presented to the user in conjunction with the “original materials.” The connection of AR to the Internet and sourcesei tnhe arlso gives u sers the ability to connect and collaborate with one another. The enhanced experiences provided by way of AR foster connections b etween u sers as well as librarians and the creators of AR applications themselves. Authors within the data seextp ect connecting with others and building relationships will make user experiences much richer in terms of how the user interacts with information and in what wa information is presented to the us e r.

The Google Blogs search was not limited to-s­‐ p LeIcSific blogs, as the search function is limited in definable search parameters. Of the 300 blog posts in the data set, only four actually include the term li brary o r refer to AR applications within libra.ri Oesne blog post alludes to archiving but does not explicitly mention a library setting. These blog postings covdeersa fotrili t y, u tility, interactivity, d iscovery t ool, a n experience, alib rary instruction ai,dp romoting a nd e nhancing the library, a ccess, a nd p roviding services to use.rs While not all of these codes are included in the three dominant categories coding for the LISTA sources, they do reflect the utilitarian quality of AR as a provider of information at its most basic. For example, AR n ies s inou orce a versatile tool enhancing aspects of the user’s library experience, a view shared with the aforementioned LISTA excerpts, from the ways services are provided for the user to the level of interactivity the patron has with relevant information whitn t he library, such as finding specific book l ocations or accessing information about the services the library offe rs.

DO YOU BELIEVE IN MAGIC? | Z AK Archiving information displayed through AR applications poses a challenge and is a necessary consideration for those i nterested in airvcihng information. Truly, AR has the potential to change archiving platforms and access to those platforms. The archiving of information presented via AR is a concern for those implementing AR for a variety of purposes. Presenting even library hours or wayfinding information for a user through AR r aalsisoes t he question of how information will be accessed, for how long, and in what form it will exist once it is no longer neede,do, r u pdated changed. The coded data suggests AR is conceptualized as a new development in digital technology worth paying attention to, at least for now, but should also be approached with some caution; users or those looking to implement AR should be careful to understanfd un tchtieonality and implications of using AR prior to adapting the technology. As reflected in the sources, books and physical spaces are potential areas for AR application and in some cases are already overlaid with AR and are enhancing user experiences.s A a whole, the conceptualization of AR is a technology with great potential to change the way users interact with information because of its ve,r ms aotbililtiyty, and direct interaction with the user’s immediate environme nt.

What I s theR ole of theUs er n i R elation to AR as itCo isn c eptualized in LIS? The u ser is the foundation of A,gR iving the technology its functionality or prompting action. Whether conceptualized as a new direction, an information soou rrpc erovider, or an enhancement, AR is essentilayl static if there is no user prompting the AR application to “act.” Without action on the user’s part, the information stored within AR applications is inert. The goal of AR is to present information in digital form within the context of the usern’sdin sugrsr,o u environment, o r reality. Codes describing AR aas n ew directio,nn ew world, o r n ew normals olidify the idea that AR is a new technological development poised to redefine not only the information landscape but also the ways users interact with tecohlnogy and information. Furthermore, references to AR as a seemingly unstoppablepo pular trendpo int to the perceived usefulness and importance of AR in the life of the user, as it is seen to raise expectations in terms of how users access information. O blog source writes, “You may have heard about augmented reality before. If you haven’t, you’ll be hearing a lot about it from now on, with the smartphone and tablet revolution n-o­‐ w in full swing.”69 T he “revolution” surrounding smartphones and tablets allsu d teo the increase in their use and sales, makintg hese devices staples in evedrayy life. This idea is parallel to user expectations in terms of online resources, as many users rely on information accessed through the Internet.70,71,72,73 T he implication is once AR applications gain more widespread use, the user will come to expect access to a wide range of information through those AR applic ations. Because AR is still met with skeptic,ias mnd for someis stillin need of further developmnte, the technology provides opportunities for librarians and their staff as those implementing and providing AR-b­‐ased services to forge new paths in AR application, becoming users of the technology “behind-t­‐ he-s­‐cenes.” The following excerpt from a LISTAur c seo highlights this view : Technological advances are beginning to fundamentally change the way that library users interact with digital information, and it is therefore essential that librarians become engaged with the relevant technology and leverage i r th reole as teachers in order to help ensure their continued relevance in the lives of clients in the t-w­‐fiernsty century7.4 Within this statement, librarians are learning and teaching about new technology. Maintaining “relevance in the lives of clients”gg seusts as the technology grows, implementers of the technology need to understand the technology. As reflected in this excerpt, on the other end is the user (or client) of the AR application after it is created and implemented. The user has the opportunity n ot only to access and experience information in new ways but also to help build and contribute to the creation and streamlining of the AR application through his or her response to the application’s functionality. The user of AR is also central to tehwe o vfi AR as informational. In a simplistic way, AR is dormant and incapable of providing, delivering, searching for, superimpo,soi rng really doing much of anything with information without user actions. In most cases with AR, users must have some type of m obile device to prompt what is often described as an AR experience. Information provided via AR applications is unlike the physical format of a book, newspaper, ma,og arzi onteher object. These physical objects exist in libraries and the like, r esidisn hge lo vnes and taking up physical space regardless of the location or presence of a user. By contrast, the information embedded within an AR application is only viewable and unlocked when the user prompts action through the viewfinder of a smartphone, tab,leo tr other mobile device. The technology is described as a catchall or endless repository for interactive information for the user, at the user’s fin gertips. Likewise, the conceptualization of AR as any kind of enhancement is also dependent on the user, though this assertion is implicit in many of the coded passages. Without user interaction prompting the AR application to overlay information onto the real environment, AR is incapable of enhancing experiences, libraries, communicatio, no r reality itself. Ehnancement, or improvement, suggests something or someone is acted on in a way that is beneficial, in,teo nrsi efmiebdedded with a stronger sense of valu e.

Much like the informational quality of AR, without the use of a mobile device handled by the user, AR i s dormant and nonexistent, unable to enhance the environment or other aspect of physical life. Without a user within a specific context, there is not much for AR to b eenchaaunsceeit exists as merely a “marker,” tucking away the desired information,it ainwga a user to come along and point a mobile device in its direction. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE This study can inform several aspects of practice. I expound on three possibilities: the clear definition of technologies like AR to creante a awareness and understanding of those technologies, development of best practices, and the need for a focus on user collaboration in the design and functionality of AR and similar technologies. The implications for practice concern both the user and the r povider of information services .

This study provides perspective, or a starting point, from which the field of LIS can begin to analyze the use and implementation of AR technology. By taking a step back to understand the current conceptualization of AR, a pcrtitioners within LIS can begin to seek consensus, identify best practices, maintain an awareness of how the technology is used and think realistically about what factors contribute to successful implementation of the technology in a given institut ion. As identified in the study, AR is seen as a new direction. It is important for those within the field to understand this perspective and to go on to identify what a new direction in information gathering organization, a nd seeking implies for the field awsh aol e and for users .

As a field, LIS can begin to have a broader discussion on what exactly AR can provide and how it can benefit user services. Such a discussion can help practitioners make sense of how this technology can work with traditional sourcesin ofofrmation. AR can be integrated with the traditional rather than act as a replacement for the traditional. This broader discussion can lead to a consensus on how best to define AR as a tool and concept. Within this study, it is evident AR is described n i myriad ways, so it is important to reflect on those descriptions, understand what the issues are surrounding t he t echnolo,gay nd collaboratively seek and identify best practic es. LIMITATIONS AND FUTURE APPLICATIO N This study is just one step in t he p rocess of understanding how new techncoolnocgeyp t iusa lized and what effect that conceptualization has on implementation. Should AR continue to grow in popularity, this study can serve as a model for future research seeking to understand concepts misinterpreted, misunderstood, o r undergoing concretede velopment. Utilizing the explicit assertion as a unit of analysis coupled with RCT can aid in investigations of other digital technologies, both in terms of implementation and end u se. The data set and the time period during which the searches otfa t h set d taook place in this study highlight two of the study’s limitations. Further studies can focus on a wider range of sources not limited to one database or blog search type and extend over a longer period of time. These limitations have potentially exucdled other voices, perspective,as nd definitions of AR, and the time element may exclude new applications or uses of AR currently being implem ented. Limitations in data analysis also exist. Content analysis is one of many research methods researchers cane m ploy to explore this topic. Ethnographic research and user interviews can lead to a deeper understanding of how users perceive ARin afonrdm ation-s­‐eeking or behavior within the AR environment. Such qualitative studies can provide insight to the rhoele u osefr t lacking in this study. Moreover, this researcher’s own admitted bias against the steadfast use of digital technologies prior to - ind­‐epth understanding is what prompted the qualitative inquiry guiding the study. Quantitative methods can also be uts oed track the popularity or perceptions of AR through close-e­‐nded questionnaires or surveys of both u sers and practitioners in t he f ield o f LIS. C itation tracking could further reveal in whsautbf ields of LIS the conversation surrounding AR is taking place, and may also uncover whether any one researcher or group of researchers is leading the conversation. Future studies can examine and expand on the results of this study. Rather than focusing on conceptualization only, researchers can study whipcrhof essional fields dominate the conversation surrounding AR and what areas of popular culture dominate the conversation or influence understanding of AR. Similarly, other studies can address the specificity of each source making explicit a ssertions a bouth is kind of technology. While qualitative in nature, the study is limited because it does not examine quantitative changes in the number of articles or blog posts alluding to AR over an extended period of time.
